Award.AwardTitle: High-speed Estimation and Control using Slow-rate Integrative Image Sensors for Adaptive Optics

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to realize high-speed adaptive optics (AO) systems that use slow-rate image sensors, such as charge-coupled device (CCD) or complementary metal?oxide?semiconductor (CMOS) arrays, for feedback. Such sensors are currently limited to only low bandwidth applications due to their relatively slow sampling rates. The proposed research will draw on the integrative nature of the image sensor to overcome this bandwidth limitation by combining estimation theory for multi-rate systems (from systems theory) and blur-to-motion algorithms (from image processing). Deliverables from this project include: (1) a system-theoretic analysis of the translation of the dynamics of an object into the spatial intensity distribution measured by an image sensor, (2) fast-rate, accurate, and robust output estimation and identification strategies using slow-rate image sensors; (3) tools for design and analysis of feedforward and feedback laws for systems with image sensors; and (4) demonstration of high-speed laser beam shaping and high-speed wavefront aberration correction for imaging systems.

The successful completion of this project will enable the use of cost-effective slow-rate image sensors in high-speed applications, which is currently infeasible because of low bandwidth restrictions. Key insights obtained will thus impact not only high-performance AO systems but also other high-speed systems that rely on image sensor feedback, such as visual-servo robots, aero-optics turbulence measurement systems, and parallelized optical tweezers. Together with industrial partners, the results of this research will be disseminated to practitioners from diverse technologies, including laser processing and wafer inspection with high speed scanning. Graduate and undergraduate students engaged in this project will be trained for a unique interdisciplinary understanding of optics, systems theory, and image processing. The project will also introduce middle and high school students to the exciting area of adaptive optics through development of passive and active optical components embedded into controllable Lego blocks.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merits

This research project was based on testing the hypothesis that slow-rate camera measurements can be used in fast dynamic systems (such as adaptive optics systems, visual servo-ing in robots) by suitably extracting information from the measured images.  The research findings of the project have shown that the information stored in a blurry image can indeed be extracted and used for obtaining better feedback control, through the following algorithms:

(1) System Identification:   Image sensors that capture information at a slow rate (~15Hz) can be used to create models that can capture much higher speed dynamics. This was demonstrated on an adaptive optics system, namely a MEMS fast steering mirror, where the system dynamics were identified up to 500 Hz using a 15 Hz camera.

(2) State Estimation: Using slow-rate image sensors, fast-rate dynamics of the system can be estimated, i.e., we can determine the states of a fast-rate system by posing the estimation problem as an optimization problem and solving this problem on-line to extract the most likely state estimate. It was also found that there may be aliasing issues that can be addressed by regularizing the optimization problem. This was demonstrated again on a 2 DOF fast steering mirror, actuated by a 1 kHz MEMS actuator, while image measurements were only obtained at 15 Hz.

(3) Signal Reconstruction:  Finally, a class of reconstruction algorithms that extract derivatives of  motion (i.e., position, velocity, etc.) of a target (or a robot) from blurry images, which could then be used for motion reconstruction at a fast-rate (100Hz). This was demonstrated on a Staubli robot arm equipped with a camera. Again, the camera measurements were obtained at a slow rate (15Hz) compared to dynamics of the Staubli arm.  

Broader Impacts

The findings of this research will enable the use of inexpensive slow-rate image sensors in applications that have typically required expensive fast measurement systems. Applications of the algorithms developed as part of this project will positively impact several engineering systems that use image feedback as measurement (for example, robots that use camera vision, adaptive optics systems, among others). The high-bandwidth signal reconstruction capability can also be used to track targets with known motion profiles with higher fidelity by extracting motion parameters from blurry images. With increasing use of cameras in several consumer goods, we envision the use of the proposed algorithms on a wide array of applications (such as camera stabilization, fast-moving object tracking applications, microscopy, etc.)

 On the educational front, the research findings have been integrated into courses at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, NY. In terms of workforce development, this project provided opportunities for the training, research experience and development of student researchers (1 PhD, 2 MS and 4 undergraduate) in the areas of optomechatronics and vision-based control. In addition to academic conferences, the findings from this project have been disseminated  at the annual Center for Automation Technologies and Systems Symposium from 2011-2014 to industrial members and affiliates, including Thorlabs, an industrial partner.
